title: Who will be elected senator from Arizona in the 2018 midterm elections?
preds:
Base Rate:
The base rate is going to start with a prediction market to start with. It’s good to put the money of people where their mouth is. For the prediction market, there is a 59% chance that there is a 59 percent chance that the republican is going to win.  The goodJudgemend open has the probability curently set at 57 percent. So we are going to set our baserate is going to be set at 58%.  According to the blogger, Prognasticating- Beek on GJO (Who has a 1.04 Brier Score) which is insane by the way. He has Sinema at a 65 percent chance of winning. So as a result, we’re going to bump down the our probability to 48 percent chance of McSally winning the race.  The poles, except for Harris, has Senema winning. And Harris’s poles are biased to begin with so that is just kind of dumb to use.  Voter Turnout: 
The state of Arizona is just under 80% white. Also, it is very nice weather in Arizona today (as I’m writing this) and tomorrow. As for other thing, this is Arizona’s most voted mid-term ever according to Garret Archer on Twitter.  So, about 65 percent of the vote was in as of Saturday was in the poll.  But let’s get down into to the brass tax. What would it take for the democrat to win in the election. There are 58,851 democratic people who have voted in the last three of four elections. There are 64,701 Republicans who have not voted. Making for just under a 6000 split.  What would it take for Sinema to win and lose: 
Here is the thing that really matters, President Trump is a (what ever the word that starts with a C and means a faster reaction, which is a catalyst). The winner will have to get Maricopa county in Arizona (where Phoenix is). And that is the large majority of the vote. 
Tuscon is going blue, which holds about 1/7th of the population in Arizona.  I’ll do some invistigating later on, but I’m going to go with Senema at 68 percent chance.

+10% Sinema Finally got to the bottom of Harris Interactive Polls and they are flawed methodology.
https://scottrasmussen.com/methodology
I now understand why 538 classfies them as C+. I would put them at C- to D. They are an online only poll which badly misses some groups and that is a sampling bias. If we discount Harris polls, all the other polls tell a similar narrative of a Dem win and now the story unfolds logically. Sinema is ahead a few days before election, that won't change. With the completion of my analysis, I've put my money where my mouth is and placed a $850 bet on Predictit with the lovely odds at 46% chance for Dem to win. I've noticed Predictit is overly sensitive to new polls without understanding poll quality, company, or context.
---- fixed accidental Dem/Rep swap --- thx to @nigster for catching it.

+10% Sinema   Finally got to the bottom of Harris Interactive Polls and they are flawed methodology.
https://scottrasmussen.com/methodology
  I now understand why 538 classfies them as C+.  I would put them at C- to D.  They are an online only poll which badly misses some groups and that is a sampling bias. If we discount Harris polls, all the other polls tell a similar narrative of a Dem win and now the story unfolds logically.  Sinema is ahead a few days before election, that won't change.  With the completion of my analysis, I've put my money where my mouth is and placed a $850 bet on Predictit with the lovely odds at 46% chance for Dem to win. I've noticed Predictit is overly sensitive to new polls without understanding poll quality, company, or context.
About 65% of estimated total Arizona votes are already in.
Arizona is still the wild west
The numbers “.7” up for the GOP it’s going to stay that way
Poll average from RCP transformed into gaussian curve.
Based on the FiveThirtyEight Senate Forecast
Based on the FiveThirtyEight Senate Forecast
I'm feeling better about chances of Sinema winning and continuing developments.
Sinema is a public relations disaster in the making.

Sinema is advertised by McSally as far left, but when you look at the details she's a centrist Democrat (voted 'with Trump' 60%~ of the time), and only people who had no intention of voting for her would ignore this. This has appeal for the general electorate of Arizona. McSally's record is 90%+. A lot is being hurled at Sinema. The Taliban moment stands out, but nothing else has come out to corroborate it as an actual position she held instead of a flippant remark made years ago. McSally accusing Sinema of treason doesn't have wide appeal.
This is based on the most recent momentum - still a very close call.
When your campaign is getting press to the effect that even if you lose your candidacy will have an important impact - you are in trouble.

Some early ballots are in and logged.  Results showing big surge in GOP voters. http://www.arizona.vote/early-ballot-statistics  However, the demographics appear to be older, likely retired voters. Not sure how that will effect the outcome of this race, but I'm going to tamper down 538 model based on this.  Predict it, has it backwards from GJO -- 40% Dem and 60% GOP.   I think Predictit is wildly optimistic for GOP and threw $800 bucks for the Dem based on stats and nothing else. My bias is that I want a woman to win. So I'm fairly safe there.
538 and predictit have diverging forecasts with predictit weighing more heavily in favor of McSally.

McSally wiped the floor Sinema in their latest debate (at least in terms of procuring votes). She focused well on the contrast in backgrounds (“You have a choice: Someone who wore the uniform, or someone who protested our troops,”), placed herself closely to Trump, and landed some tough blows on Sinema's previous (unwelcome) stances on Healthcare and Social Security. She's building up momentum at just the right time.
But let's not get ahead of ourselves...
Kysten is all in on Medicaid Expansion.
I think the # of Democratic leaning votes is under reported so the Democrat has a better chance of winning
I just don’t think Arizona has changed that much
Sinema hates on Arizona - calling it a methlab democracy....
Latest poll has McSally up 6%, so revising my previous prediction. Are we seeing the effects of Kavanaugh? Perhaps... Updates to follow.

Arizona has a tendency to sway the political party pendulum every election from democrat to republican or vice versa.  I looked at the history of every past governor of Arizona to come to my conclusion. The current Governor is republican and the governor before him was also republican. Arizona overall has had more democrats as their governors throughout history. Sinema has a higher chance of being elected to the senate due to the history and turnout of past elections. I am giving McSally 15% because she is higher in the polls. Polls are not always accurate.  Lastly, it depends on voter turn out.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/arizona/ As of Aug 8, Sinema had raised $10.5 mil to McSally's $7.6 mil, and still had half again as much cash on hand. https://www.opensecrets.org/races/summary?cycle=2018&id=AZS2

McSally needs to pick up middle of the road voters but can't and Sinema already has proven she can.  Plus, Meghan McCain doesn't like McSally and Trump does.  McSally will have to placate the base and therefore leave everyone else to vote for Sinema or to stay home. https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2018/08/29/can-sinema-mcsally-live-up-mccain-legacy/1047897002/
51 Mcsally puts me significantly in opposition to the crowd.   Good enough, although I thnk the chances are greater.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/arizona/ As of Aug 8, Sinema had raised $10.5 mil to McSally's $7.6 mil, and still had half again as much cash on hand. https://www.opensecrets.org/races/summary?cycle=2018&id=AZS2
Nothing complicated here, Sinema has a small but persistent polling lead in a race with no incumbency advantage and she has raised more money than McSally.

Sinema is an unusually good campaigner. Arizona is trending to the Democratic Party. The ongoing cruel immigration policies on southern border will cause a significant uptick of voting by Democratic leaning hispanics.
I think Sinema is a viable challenger for McSally and is likely to win.   It's not a sure thing as it is Arizona after all.

538 deluxe forecast synthesizes polling data and corrects for pollster bias. It uses campaign fundraising as a proxy in districts where polling data is scarce. Finally, it adds in expert ratings from the Cook Political Report, among others.

This is a close race at the moment, however, by election day the turnout will favor the Republicans as the midterm becomes more nationalized than local at all levels.  Economy, breakthrough news on foreign affairs and a returning attention to politics by many 2016 Republican voters will decide the election.   Whereas Democrat voters have maintained a high level of political attention following the 2016 election and thereby influenced surveys on voting intentions for the midterms, a large number of citizens who voted Repubican in 2016 are not usually interested in day to day politics. They are silent but in the last week or two before the voting they will take interest and they will be again the "unexpected" voters who will cause predicted election results to be off the mark.

RCP average has Sinema up 2.4% with the most recent polls (Fox & CNN) having her up 3% and 7% respectively.
Still a toss up.
Updates to come.
Close but former Warthog combat 'raq and 'ghan pilot should get the nod.
Guess based on the behavior of Republican.  I think the country is losing appetite for irrational candidates
